utterances: Joe's with us from Baton Rouge in Louisiana.
Yes, I don't remember who it was that said it, but in the lead up to World War II, somebody was quoted saying, if it's war or Eleanor, by God, give me war.
If it's war or Eleanor - speaking of the president's then wife, or then president's wife, Eleanor Roosevelt...
Again, not one of those zingers that went down in history, I guess.

But going back to 1992, when the Republicans criticized - now Bill Clinton had been the governor of Arkansas, and Al Gore was just, you know, a freshman or first-term senator, the Republicans said that the only foreign policy experience that Bill Clinton had was when they had breakfast once at the International House of Pancakes.
Pat Buchanan's line, I think that was.

But I wanted to ask you, there's a - you have, Chris, a bunch of quotes from Winston Churchill in this book, and regrettably, not my favorite - or actually, I guess, I'm pleased, because then I can tell you the joke, and the fact of the matter is I've never checked it to find out if it's true, because, well, it's a really good story that during the Casablanca conference, Winston Churchill and Franklin Roosevelt were there, and for the first time, FDR got to meet Charles de Gaulle, the Free French leader who'd been a thorn in Churchill's side for any number of years already.
And after the meeting, de Gaulle leaves the room, and Churchill goes in to see President Roosevelt, and Roosevelt looks at him and says, my God, he really does think he's Joan of Arc, doesn't he?
And Churchill replied, yes, and my generals won't let me burn him.
How closely do you check good stories like that?
Well, there's - we were speaking about apocryphal stories.

Back in '48, one of my favorites was the - Thomas Dewey, who everyone thought would be the next president, including Thomas Dewey, and the day of the election, he turns to his wife and he says, tomorrow night, how's it going to feel to go to bed with the man who's going to be president for the next four years?

Well, it didn't turn out Dewey's way, and the next morning, the Deweys are at breakfast and he's crestfallen, the worst day of his life, and as a wonderful wife she is, she sidles up next to him and says, well, Tom, is Harry Truman coming over here tonight, or am I going over to his house?
There's another one along those lines from the famous senator from Maine, Margaret Chase Smith, asked once what she would do if she woke up in the White House one morning.
I would wake up, apologize profusely and leave at once.
Apologize to the president's wife, I think.
Here's - this is from Susan, emailing us from Media, Pennsylvania.
This was a self-deprecating comment made, to the best of my information, by former Chief of Staff John Sununu.
When asked why people take an instant dislike to him.
Let's see if we can get Shay on the line.
Shay is with us from Salt Lake City in Utah.
I really liked the one that Mike Huckabee did recently on Mitt Romney, when he was, like, people want the guy that they work with, not the guy that they laid off.
I thought that was a good one.
That's not a bad line, and Mike Huckabee, that campaign, Chris, they seem to have a lot of good one-liners.
I think - you know, you mentioned Al Franken, a comedian, running for Senate, and Mike Huckabee seems to be a politician running for comedian.
So, everything's all mixed up nowadays.
A good insult, yeah, I think a good insult in this campaign was another McCain-Romney, where after Romney attacked him, McCain said, never wrestle with a pig.
You get dirty and the pig likes it.
One from James Reston regarding Richard Nixon, he inherited some good instincts from his Quaker forbearers, but by diligent hard work, he overcame them.
And you don't think of Richard Nixon as, you know, just a bucket of yuks, necessarily, but there is one really good one from Nixon in your book.

After hearing John Kennedy's inaugural address in 1961, Richard Nixon, who had narrowly lost to Kennedy, bumped into Ted Sorensen, one of JFK speechwriters, and said, I wish I had said some of those things.
Sorensen asked, the part about, ask not what your country can do for you?
No, Nixon replied, the part that starts, I do solemnly swear.

Well, there was the line they asked President Eisenhower about Vice President Nixon, and they asked him if he could - a reporter asked him to say how Nixon - his contributions during his eight years as vice president, and Eisenhower said something like, well, if you gave me a week or two, I could think of something.
